message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms including a limp favoring one leg, mild tenderness in one area, and decreased range of motion suggest Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, which is a childhood condition that affects the hip. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis usually presents with sudden hip or knee pain after trauma. Developmental dysplasia of the hip is either present at birth or develops within the first year of life. Viral-induced synovitis does not explain the decreased range of motion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of a limp favoring the right leg, decreased range of motion of the left hip, and mild tenderness on deep palpation of the left lumbar region suggest Legg-Calve-Perthes disease. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis typically has more severe pain and difficulty bearing weight. Developmental dysplasia of the hip usually presents earlier in life and has a more gradual onset. Viral-induced synovitis typically resolves within a few weeks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a limp favoring the right leg, however, there is decreased range of motion of the left hip, mild tenderness on deep palpation of the left lumbar region, and no erythema, edema, or warmth. These are consistent with Legg-Calve-Perthes disease. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis and developmental dysplasia of the hip typically have a pain that is localized to the hip, groin, or thigh. Viral-induced synovitis usually subsides within 10 days to 3 weeks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with a limp favoring the right leg and decreased range of motion of the left hip, suggesting Legg-Calve-Perthes disease. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis is usually bilateral and presents with acute onset of limp and pain. Developmental dysplasia of the hip may have a positive Ortolani or Barlow test. Viral-induced synovitis usually resolves within 1-2 weeks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is Legg-Calve-Perthes disease. This condition affects the blood supply to the femoral head, leading to avascular necrosis of the bone. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis would present with pain, not necessarily limp. Developmental dysplasia of the hip would be picked up on newborn examinations, unless it is mild. Viral-induced synovitis would present with pain and swelling, not necessarily limp.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with a limp favoring one leg and decreased range of motion of the hip, which are suggestive of Legg-Calve-Perthes disease. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis typically presents with acute onset of hip pain and inability to bear weight, while developmental dysplasia of the hip usually presents in infancy or early childhood. Viral-induced synovitis is usually self-limited and would not present with a prolonged limp.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, which is characterized by limping, decreased range of motion of the hip, and mild tenderness in the lumbar region. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis and developmental dysplasia of the hip are also possible causes of hip pain in children, but the presented symptoms make Legg-Calve-Perthes disease the most likely. Viral-induced synovitis typically presents with joint pain and swelling, but the presented symptoms do not suggest joint inflammation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including a limp favoring one leg, decreased range of motion of the hip, and tenderness on deep palpation, suggest Legg-Calve-Perthes disease. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis and developmental dysplasia of the hip usually have more significant pain, inability to bear weight, and a positive Ortolani sign. Viral-induced synovitis is less likely to last for 6 months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with a limp favoring the right leg and decreased range of motion of the left hip, which are common signs of Legg-Calve-Perthes disease. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis and developmental dysplasia of the hip can also cause hip pain and limping but would have different exam findings. Viral-induced synovitis is a possibility but would typically resolve within a few weeks, not 6 months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s age and symptoms are consistent with Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, a condition where the femoral head undergoes avascular necrosis. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis usually presents with acute onset of hip pain after trauma or during growth spurt. Developmental dysplasia of the hip presents with limited hip abduction and dysplastic acetabulum on imaging. Viral-induced synovitis typically resolves within a few weeks.
